awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Data Analytics and Physics-Based Insights into Vehicle Mobility Patterns
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to provide new insight to consumers on their vehicle use, to inform environmental and economic impact. Unfortunately, typical car buyers currently do not understand their mobility patterns, and in particular how electric vehicle (EV) fuel costs and range viability will impact their day-to-day lives.  Thus, prospective car buyers may not appreciate the potential financial and practical savings.  This SBIR Phase II project proposes to support the development of data collection, processing, and analytical methods to measure an individual's (or fleet) driving tendencies to predict the value and viability of EV use.  This can potentially save billions of gallons of avoided petroleum use as well as hundreds of billions in associated costs, and dramatically reduced emissions. 

The proposed project advances data science, machine learning, and convex optimization techniques to estimate vehicle performance.  This project has three stages: (1) develop mathematical and physics-based algorithms for predicting the energy or charge requirements and range viability for any electric vehicle on any trip, including uncertainty bounds on the calculated results; (2) integrate the trip energy calculations to develop algorithms that predict and optimize EV charging deployments; (3) develop algorithms for use at scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our company provides app- and web-based tools that help car buyers derisk the purchase of electric vehicles (EVs). By leveraging data analysis and physics-based modeling integrated into effective app- and web-based products, we help consumers and fleets to reduce the uncertainties they face when considering an EV. For consumers, we help reduce uncertainties on range viability and charging needs. For fleets, we reduce uncertainties on required charging infrastructure and grid load profiles. Our analytical process to personalize EV education is organized into three steps: 1) Collecting data on one’s own driving patterns, 2) Analyzing that data with vehicle energy models, and 3) Providing actionable insights that show how different vehicles on the market compare for one’s own driving.

Towards our company’s overall goals for supporting car buyers when considering an EV, in this SBIR Phase II project, we accomplished the following technical objectives:

Technical Objective 1: Developing methodologies for EV car buyers and drivers to plan their trips and alleviate any danger of running out of charge.

Technical Objective 2: Developing methodologies for fleet car buyers to plan and optimize the charging infrastructure they deploy to support EVs in their fleets, and for electric utilities to forecast load growth from EVs deployed by fleets.

Technical Objective 3: Integrate the methodologies and algorithms from Objectives 1 and 2 into apps and software that allows consumers and fleets to overcome the risks and uncertainties preventing EV uptake.


Last Modified: 12/10/2024
Modified by: Samveg Saxena
